title.justification: Title of the paper as provided in the user query and the detailed analysis.

extractions.description: The paper studies the problem of ensuring group fairness in the context of Reinforcement Learning (RL). It proposes algorithms for both tabular and high-dimensional Deep-RL settings that ensure fairness throughout the learning process and achieve sub-linear regret. The research highlights the challenges posed by fairness constraints and presents empirical results on various benchmarks.

type.justification: The paper presents empirical results and validation on various RL benchmarks to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.
type.quote: we report encouraging empirical results on various traditional RL-inspired benchmarks showing that our algorithms display the desired behavior

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on developing and studying algorithms within the scope of Reinforcement Learning.
name.quote: We pose and study the problem of satisfying fairness in the online Reinforcement Learning (RL) setting.

name.justification: The paper addresses fairness constraints within RL, making 'Fairness in AI' a significant sub-research field.
name.quote: the problem of satisfying fairness in the online Reinforcement Learning (RL) setting

name.justification: PPO is used as the basis for developing fair RL algorithms in the paper.
name.quote: based on the constrained policy improvement performance bounds proposed by Achiam et al. (2017) and allows us to extend the Deep-RL algorithms such as PPO (Schulman et al., 2017) to our setting

is_contributed.justification: The PPO model itself is not a new contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: based on the constrained policy improvement performance bounds proposed by Achiam et al. (2017) and allows us to extend the Deep-RL algorithms such as PPO (Schulman et al., 2017) to our setting

is_executed.justification: PPO is used and executed as part of the experiments in the paper.
is_executed.quote: based on the constrained policy improvement performance bounds proposed by Achiam et al. (2017) and allows us to extend the Deep-RL algorithms such as PPO (Schulman et al., 2017) to our setting

is_compared.justification: PPO based approaches are compared to the proposed fair algorithms.
is_compared.quote: we compare the baselines across three different levels of fairness thresholds

referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Schulman et al. introduces PPO.

name.justification: PyTorch is mentioned as the library used for implementing the Deep-RL algorithms.
name.quote: We use PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019) for implementing the Deep-RL algorithms.

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Paszke et al. describes the PyTorch library.
referenced_paper_title.quote: PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library

name.justification: MuJoCo is used for the physics simulation in the continuous control tasks.
name.quote: modifications to suit our fairness setting... based on the MuJoCo guidelines (Todorov et al., 2012)

referenced_paper_title.value: MuJoCo: A Physics Engine for Model-Based Control
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Todorov et al. introduces MuJoCo.
referenced_paper_title.quote: MuJoCo: A Physics Engine for Model-Based Control
